FacilityName: Fraser Papers Inc - Park Falls Operations

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

The people of the Fraser Papers Park Falls mill are committed to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public and the environment.   Our environmental policy states:
We will continually identify, evaluate and control the risks associated with our operations.  We shall have procedures in place to prevent and respond to emergencies.

As part of this commitment, we have established a system to ensure the safe storage, handling and use of dangerous chemicals used in our manufacturing operations.  One component of that system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage chemical risks, and which complies with the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agencys Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  

One of the RMP rule requirements is the preparation of a risk management plan (RMPlan) which identifies certain dangerous chemicals possessed in quantities exceeding specified thresholds, and which describes the plans in-place to manage the risks to the public that they present.  This document is intended to satisfy that RMPlan requirement and to provide the public with a description of the chemical risk management program at the Fraser Papers Park Falls mill.


Accidental Release Prevention Strategy

Our chemical risk management plan consists of numerous policies and procedures intended to minimize the risk that dangerous chemicals pose to our employees and the public.  In general, they are:

1. We limit the use of dangerous chemicals by first considering less dangerous alternatives.  When a dangerous chemical is selected for use we consider the potential harmful affects to our employees and the public, and take steps to eliminate or minimize the risks identified 
 
2. We prevent releases of the dangerous chemicals we use.  When a dangerous chemical is used, we design, build, operate and maintain appropriate facilities and equipment.   All employees using dange

rous chemicals are trained in their  proper use and the equipment involved.
 
3. We are prepared to limit the damage caused by an accidental release.  We train all our employees in basic emergency procedures, and maintain an in-house "level-A" hazardous material (HAZMAT) team to actively intervene in all dangerous chemical emergencies.  In addition, we train for emergencies with local emergency response agencies, and participate actively on the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).



RMP Rule-Covered Dangerous Chemicals In Use 

The FPPF mill is a partially integrated pulp and paper manufacturing facility.  To produce sulfite chemical pulp we use 2 dangerous chemicals in sufficient quantity to be covered by the RMP rule.  They are described as follows:

                                Chemical                                                Maximum Quantity On Site
                              Sulfur Dioxide                                                         56,500 lbs
                                 Chlorine                                                             180,000 lbs


Offsite Consequence Analyses

We have performed mathematical modeling exercises to estimate the off-site consequences of a release of sulfur dioxide or chlorine from our mill.  The analyses include both worst-case, and more realistic, alternative release models.  Given the chemical risk management program in-place, the likelihood of a worst-case release scenario occurring is extremely remote.  The alternative scenarios selected are ones that could conceivably happen and which have the potential for significant off-site consequences. 

The objective of performing the off-site consequence analyses are to determine the distances from the mill where danger to the public might occur because of an accidental release (called the end-point distance) so that local emergency response agencies can complete the necessary emergency response planning.  

Sulfur Dioxide Release Scenarios

Th

e worst-case release scenario for sulfur dioxide is the complete discharge of our 56,500 lb. storage tank over a 10-minute period.  That event would place an estimated  5,700 people within the 8.1 end-point distance circle.

The alternative release scenario for sulfur dioxide is a failure of the hose used to transfer liquified sulfur dioxide from a semi-trailer to our storage tank.  In that event, approximately 444 lbs. of sulfur dioxide would escape in the 30 seconds required for the personnel present to respond.  That event would place an estimated 210 people at risk within the = mile end point distance circle.

Chlorine Release Scenarios

The worst-case release scenario for chlorine is the complete discharge of a 90-ton rail car over a 10 minute period.  That event would place an estimated 7,700 people at risk within the 14 mile end-point distance circle.

The alternative release scenario for chlorine is a failure of the hose used to transfer liquified chlorine from a railcar  to our processes.  In that event, approximately 15,000 lbs. of chlorine would escape in the 60 minutes required for the personnel present to respond.  That event would place an estimated 110 people at risk within the 0.3 mile end point distance circle.

Accidental Chemical Release Prevention Program

The accidental chemical release program at the Fraser Papers - Park Falls mill consists of these elements:

Process Safety Information

We maintain a variety of technical, operating and engineering materials that are used for training our employees and as a reference resource to help ensure the safe use of sulfur dioxide and chlorine. 

Process Hazards Analysis (PHA)

We perform and periodically update systematic PHAs of the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems to help identify and eliminate system, equipment and process hazards that could cause an accidental release. 

Operating Procedures

We use detailed operating and maintenance procedures to train our employees in the safe performance of th

eir work, and to serve as an on-going reference guide.

Compliance Audits

We conduct periodic compliance audits to verify that our risk management system is   operating as intended, and in compliance with the RMP rule.  All deficiencies identified in the audit are corrected promptly.

Incident Investigations

We investigate all incidents that cause, or might have caused, a release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide to the environment.  The results are documented and appropriate corrective measures implemented.

5-Year Accident History

We have had no accidents that resulted in the release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide in the past 5 years.

Emergency Response Program

We have a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP rule and which has been communicated to the Price County and Park Falls emergency agencies.  We conduct full scale emergency exercises in conjunction with these and other regional agencies to ensure our readiness to deal with emergency situations involving chlorine and sulfur dioxide.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

We constantly strive to improve the safety of our chlorine and sulfur dioxide facilities and processes.  Our most recent review did not identify the need for any changes.
